Dr Kunkel has a very stiff, no nonsense (lack of) personality. He's quick to the point, doesn't mince words or waste time. He comes in looking a bit like a butcher with that x-ray proof apron on, tells you exactly what he's going to do, does it, then swiftly moves on to his next patient.

Some people might find this a bit off-putting because he's so rigid that it makes you feel like he doesn't care about you. But when I'm looking for someone to do what basically comes down to minor surgical procedures on my spine I'm not trying to find a friend or judge their ability to do their job on how much they make me smile. In this situation I think it's a good thing to have a physician who is extremely technical and hyperfocused on his work and not just a people pleaser.

From my experience I deduced that giving injections and doing nerve ablations to a large number of people is the bulk of his job. I have never interacted with Dr Kunkel outside of the outpatient procedure center; I never met him at his pain management office, other physicians always handled my appointments there, so I believe the only decisions that he made about my care revolved around my injections and nerve ablations.

Both my Dad and I had procedures done by Dr Kunkel on a regular basis for a couple of years and we always found him to be quite professional. He takes his job very seriously! Sometimes our injections helped, sometimes they didn't, but I don't think that had anything to do with what he did or didn't do.

There are a series of steps that have to be followed for a doctor to figure out exactly what area is causing the problem and get to the point of doing something more permanent to help relieve the pain. It can be frustrating and time consuming - when a person is in pain they are seeking immediate relief and what he does doesn't usually give that.

I will say that the extremely long waits in the procedure center got REALLY old, but I don't know how much of that was his fault directly. Almost every time (for both my father and I) the wait past when our appointment was scheduled was HOURS. It sucked extra bad because we weren't able to eat or drink anything past midnight, and of course it's hard to sit there for so long when you're in pain.

But all the nurses were always really kind and fast at doing what they do. The ladies who assist Dr Kunkel in the actual procedure room constantly cracked me up - they were funny, super upbeat and jamming out to music. Everyone was as gentle as they could be - of course I experienced pain while that needle was being jammed in my spine, but they tried hard to be careful when it came to everything else and I was usually offered some sort of pain relief prior whenever possible.

I can understand why some people have given him such low reviews, but I've had far worse doctors and think he deserves some respect for having such a difficult job and doing the technical aspects of it so well. Pain management is hard, especially back pain. It's a long road with lots of hits & misses that sometimes ends in surgery or never gets resolved at all.

I can't say that I ever got anything more than some temporary relief from the procedures that were done, and sometimes they even caused me more agony. But I didn't continue with them so I'm not sure what sort of outcome I would of had in the end, if there was ever an end. I have major issues throughout my entire spine because of a degenerative disease, but somebody who had an injury or damage at one level might have better outcomes than those of us who are in chronic, widespread pain.|Attempted nerve blocks on both sides of my neck left me hemorrhaging into my chest. He offered no guarantees but was optimistic of a successful outcome. My grandmother decided to do a form of injections in her joints and back. column48: Will the allograft containing human umbilical cord tissue (HUCT) stem cells treatment work for me to resolve my joint pain and regenerate tissue?
column49:
While the majority of our patients report improvements after treatment, no medical procedure or drug, including knee replacement surgery, stem cell injections, or stem cell augmented surgery, works 100% of the time, and no drug or medical procedure comes with a guarantee. Many factors determine the outcome: age, weight, general health, the extent of damage, physical activity, adhering to post-treatment instructions, smoking, drinking, medications, concomitant diseases like diabetes and heart disease, to name several.

The key is having an experienced physician with all tools at his or her disposal to evaluate each patient individually and determine what the best course of action is based upon the many factors involved. It could be rehab. It could be stem cell injections. It could be stem cell augmented, minimally invasive surgery. It could even be a stem cell-augmented knee replacement in some cases.

Of course, there are cases for which stem cell + biologics injections alone are unlikely to help. That's one of the reasons for stories about getting "stem cell injections" that didn't work. In some of those cases, the doctor probably shouldn't have done them in the first place because they were unlikely to work. In others, the doctors are using inferior products that they haven't tested in a lab themselves. They have no idea what's actually in them, which is usually no stem cells, very small numbers of stem cells, or even non-viable (dead) cells. We are Montana's original and longest-running stem cell provider and we pride ourselves in always and only using the most ethical and effective stem cells for our patients. If there was a better source or treatment, we'd be using them/it.
